text: Proprietary AI systems threaten societal control by limiting information access to a few companies.

claim.text: Proprietary AI systems threaten societal control by limiting information access to a few companies.

text: AGI will not escape human control and will not kill all humans.

claim.text: AGI will not escape human control and will not kill all humans.

text: Large language models lack essential characteristics of intelligence such as reasoning, planning, and persistent memory.

claim.text: Large language models lack essential characteristics of intelligence such as reasoning, planning, and persistent memory.

text: Most of our knowledge is derived from interaction with the physical world, not from language.

claim.text: Most of our knowledge is derived from interaction with the physical world, not from language.

nodes.text: Most of our knowledge is derived from interaction with the physical world, not from language.
nodes.label: Most knowledge from physical interaction
nodes.reason: The claim that most knowledge comes from interaction with the physical world lacks credible support; independent research indicates that language is crucial for transmitting knowledge and facilitating understanding, suggesting a more balanced role for both language and experience.

research.title: You Don’t Need Words to Think
research.summary: Neuroscientist Evelina Fedorenko's research challenges the idea that language is essential for thought.  Her studies, using advanced brain imaging, show that high-level cognitive processes, such as problem-solving and social reasoning, occur independently of language.  While language facilitates communication and knowledge transmission,  examples of animal cognition and cases of aphasia (loss of speech) demonstrate that complex thought processes are possible without the use of words.  Therefore, the assertion that most knowledge is derived from interaction with the physical world, rather than language, is supported by this research.
highlights: And in fact, most of the things that you probably learned about the world, you learned through language and not through direct experience with the world. You can easily imagine how it would confer evolutionary advantages: by facilitating cooperative activities, transmitting knowledge about how to build tools and conveying social knowledge. As people started living in larger groups, it became more important to keep track of various social relationships. Also, it’s very hard to transmit knowledge to future generations, and language allows us to do that very effectively. In line with the idea that we have language to communicate, there is accumulating evidence from the past few decades that shows that various properties that human languages have—there are about 7,000 of them spoken and signed across the world—are optimized for efficiently transmitting information, making things easy to perceive, easy to understand, easy to produce and easy to learn for kids.

research.title: DRAFT 2/13/97
research.summary: This research uses simulated evolution to compare two methods of category acquisition: "sensorimotor toil" (learning through direct experience) and "symbolic theft" (learning from descriptions).  The study finds that "symbolic theft" consistently outperforms "sensorimotor toil," suggesting this is the adaptive advantage of language.  However, the authors emphasize that initial categories must still be learned through direct experience to avoid an infinite regress ("symbol grounding problem").  Therefore, while language significantly accelerates knowledge acquisition, it ultimately relies on a foundation of sensorimotor interaction with the physical world.
highlights: Language is famously silent in the archeological and paleontological record, requiring interpreters to speak for it; but it is the validity of those very interpretations that Perhaps we need to take a step back, and look at our linguistic capacity from the proverbial Martian anthropologist's perspective: Human beings

research.title:
Yann LeCun on X: "To people who claim that "thinking and reasoning require language", here is a problem:
Imagine standing at the North Pole of the Earth.
Walk in any direction, in a straight line, for 1 km.
Now turn 90 degrees to the left.
Walk for as long as it takes to pass your starting point.…" / X
research.summary: Yann LeCun's tweet presents a spatial reasoning problem to challenge the assertion that "thinking and reasoning require language."  The problem involves calculating the distance traveled after walking 1km from the North Pole, turning 90 degrees left, and walking until the starting point is passed.  The solution requires spatial visualization and calculation, not necessarily linguistic processing, supporting the idea that knowledge can be derived from physical world interaction rather than solely language.
highlights: To people who claim that "thinking and reasoning require language", here is a problem: Imagine standing at the North Pole of the Earth. Walk in any direction, in a straight line, for 1 km. Now turn 90 degrees to the left. Walk for as long as it takes to pass your starting point. Have you walked: 1.

nodes.text: Sensory experiences such as touch, sight, and hearing are the primary source of knowledge.
nodes.label: Sensory experience primary
nodes.reason: While sensory experiences play a significant role in knowledge acquisition, they are not the sole source; language and interpretation are also crucial in forming knowledge, indicating a more nuanced understanding is needed.

research.title: On the role of senses in education
research.summary: This paper introduces a multi-sensory method and software for teaching algorithms, arguing that engaging multiple senses improves learning.  While multi-sensory learning, particularly its benefits for children, has been studied, its application to older students and algorithm instruction remains less explored. The authors contend that current methods, like simulations, underutilize the brain's capacity for sensory processing. Their approach incorporates auditory (sonification) and kinesthetic (drumming) elements alongside visual and auditory ones, creating a closed-loop interaction for enhanced learning.  The paper cites research supporting the idea that sensory experiences are crucial to knowledge acquisition and memory formation, highlighting the dual coding theory which posits that verbal and non-verbal inputs (visual, auditory, kinesthetic) are processed by different but interacting subsystems in the brain.
highlights: The more senses involved does not only mean more information, better perception, more efficient memorising and deeper understanding, but ensures the same chance for students with different Copyright © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

research.title: Learning through Senses in Geography, Evaluation and Opportunities
research.summary: This 2013 research paper by Dhimitri and Sinani explores how sensory experiences shape geographical knowledge acquisition across different age groups and educational levels.  The authors argue that sensory perception is fundamental to learning and analyze how various teaching tools can enhance sensory learning in geography.  A case study using the textbook "Geography 11" is included, supported by statistical methods.  The study focuses on explaining the process of learning through senses and how it changes with age.
highlights: Realized through senses and perceptions, it changes by age and individuals. It plays an irreplaceable role in the learning process. It is works together with logic recognizing accompanying and fulfilling the learning to each individual. In the paper there are presented the change that is gained during age growth versus sensory recognition. Also we are trying to treat different ways of realization of sensory knowledge in the subject of geography in different cycles of education.

research.title: Sense experience is the only source of knowledge
research.summary: This essay argues that while sense experience (touch, sight, hearing, etc.) provides the raw data for knowledge, it is not the sole source.  The author contends that our brains interpret sensory data, creating information which reason then uses to build knowledge. Language plays a crucial role in this process, shaping our interpretation of sensory information.  The essay acknowledges the importance of sense experience in various fields like art, history, and science, but highlights its limitations and weaknesses as the only pathway to knowledge.  It uses real-life examples from the human sciences and history to illustrate its points.
highlights: This way of knowing is also shared with language as a way of knowing, the data is information and there in the interpretation of data where it is stated that language is an important factor. It is also important to consider the terms 'individual' sense experience and 'sense perception'. There are various forms of sense experience in the form of art, history, human and natural sciences which is a way of gathering information provided it is corroborated by sense perception. Sense perception is the act of perceiving the data obtained by sense experience and the most common and direct form is through observation; a good example is using one's eyes to observe an event or incident and gather information. Essentially sense experience provides concrete, raw data and information that is the building blocks for knowledge.

nodes.text: Language plays a secondary role in knowledge acquisition.
nodes.label: Language secondary
nodes.reason: The independent research suggests that language is crucial for efficient knowledge transfer and communication, indicating that it plays a significant role in knowledge acquisition rather than a secondary one.

research.title: You Don’t Need Words to Think
research.summary: Neuroscientist Evelina Fedorenko's research indicates that language and thought are distinct processes in the brain.  While language facilitates communication and knowledge transmission, high-level cognitive functions like problem-solving and social reasoning can occur independently of language.  Studies of individuals with aphasia, who lack the ability to speak, demonstrate that complex thought processes are possible without linguistic expression, supporting the idea that language plays a secondary, albeit important, role in knowledge acquisition.
highlights: In line with the idea that we have language to communicate, there is accumulating evidence from the past few decades that shows that various properties that human languages have—there are about 7,000 of them spoken and signed across the world—are optimized for efficiently transmitting information, making things easy to perceive, easy to understand, easy to produce and easy to learn for kids. We know from brain evolution that many parts of the cortical sheet \[the outer layer of the brain\] expanded a lot in humans. These parts of the brain contain several distinct functional systems. Language is one of them. But there’s also a system that allows us to reason about other minds.

research.title: Language of knowledge and knowledge of language. Towards plurilingual sciences?
research.summary: This research paper examines the role of language in higher education, specifically in French-speaking Swiss universities.  It investigates whether institutional language policies promote or hinder multilingualism in academic settings. The study finds that while a clear, institution-wide language policy is beneficial, the specific disciplines significantly influence language choices, suggesting that language's role in knowledge acquisition isn't uniformly secondary.  The impact of this finding on the relationship between language and knowledge acquisition is explored.
highlights: The study brochures of different disciplines and faculties will be perused and discussed with reference to language needs and language proficiency requirements. It appears that if an explicit and institutionalised language policy is desirable for a coherent and productive teaching and learning outcome on the vertical scale, the influence of the nature of the disciplines on the relation they have with language is a substantial factor in determining language choices. A clear overview of the relationships between factors will contribute to a successful top-down decision.

research.title: The importance of language in international knowledge transfer
research.summary: This article's references do not directly support or refute the assertion that language plays a secondary role in knowledge acquisition.  The listed research focuses on the impact of language fluency on knowledge sharing within multinational corporations and the role of language in knowledge transfer, suggesting its importance rather than a secondary role.  More information is needed to assess the claim's validity.
highlights: Download references ||||I|||| Skip to main content The importance of language in international knowledge transfer Management International Review volume 48, pages 339–360 ( 2008 )Cite this article * In this article, we examine the effects of language on the transfer of knowledge within multinational companies. We unbundle language from the culture box and use the basic communication model to show how language affects all stages.

nodes.text: Knowledge acquisition relies predominantly on empirical evidence and practical experience.
nodes.label: Empirical evidence predominant
nodes.reason: The claim about knowledge acquisition relying predominantly on empirical evidence and practical experience is supported by the emphasis on practical knowledge in various sources; however, theoretical knowledge also plays a significant role, which is not fully acknowledged in the claim.

research.title: Training Plays an Essential Role in Delivering Practical Knowledge
research.summary: This article, "Training Plays an Essential Role in Delivering Practical Knowledge," by Martha Apodaca, argues that effective training is crucial for acquiring practical knowledge.  While the full text isn't provided, the title and metadata strongly suggest the article supports the user query's assertion that knowledge acquisition benefits significantly from practical experience.  The article, published in *The Way Ahead* in 2016, likely details the methods and importance of training in providing hands-on learning.
highlights: Practical knowledge can be defined as “knowledge attained through action” while theoretical knowledge is “knowledge attained through established facts or thoughts.” One of my favorite quotes on this matter is from the recently deceased Yogi Berra, an American professional baseball catcher, manager, and coach. Yogi was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1972. In addition, he was famous for his paradoxical quotes. We are living in exponential times and knowledge is at the center of it. By the time you graduate, the skills you learned in college will be outdated and it does not stop there.

research.title: Knowledge acquisition
research.summary: This chapter from a study on health-care commissioning investigates how commissioners access research evidence and other knowledge sources for decision-making.  While acknowledging the intertwined nature of knowledge acquisition and transformation, the study separates them for reporting purposes.  The research focuses on PCT/CCG commissioners and uses data from eight case studies (including examples like Carnford CCG, a financially struggling organization heavily reliant on data-driven tools, and Deanshire CCG, a more confident organization focused on governance and partnerships).  The study does not explicitly state that knowledge acquisition relies *predominantly* on empirical evidence and practical experience, but rather explores the various sources commissioners utilize.
highlights: Results were published on its website ‘to impart knowledge of how it’s been applied in different areas’ and establish ‘rigour’ (Stan, commercial analyst). Consultants from the company regularly attended academic conferences where they gave presentations on the tool and made ‘opportune’ contacts (Katie, commercial consultant). Engaging academics was important to the success of rolling out the tool. > > And how important do you think universities are in terms of expansion? > > Extremely.

research.title: Knowledge Acquisition
research.summary: The provided text focuses on knowledge acquisition for expert systems, not on whether it relies predominantly on empirical evidence and practical experience.  While the text describes methods involving observing experts solving problems and extracting knowledge through interviews, it doesn't explicitly address the epistemological basis of the knowledge being acquired.  Therefore, the statement in the query cannot be confirmed or refuted based on this text alone.
highlights: There are three main topic areas central to knowledge acquisition First, the domain must be evaluated to determine if the type Second, the source of expertise must be identified Third, if the major source of expertise is a person, the specific knowledge acquisition techniques and participants need to be

nodes.text: Touch, sight, and hearing are fundamental senses.
nodes.label: Touch, sight, hearing
nodes.reason: The claim is supported by independent research which confirms that touch, sight, and hearing are indeed fundamental senses among the five basic human senses, as recognized in scientific literature.

research.title: The five (and more) human senses - Live Science
research.summary: The article confirms that touch, sight, and hearing are fundamental human senses.  It describes touch as the first sense to develop, involving various sensations (pressure, temperature, pain) communicated to the brain via skin neurons.  Sight is detailed as a complex process involving light reflection, the cornea bending light, and its passage through the pupil and lens to the brain.  While the article doesn't explicitly detail the mechanics of hearing, it includes it within the list of fundamental senses.
highlights: There are five basic human senses: touch, sight, hearing, smell and taste. The sensing organs associated with each sense send information to the [brain](https://www.livescience.com/29365-human-brain.html) to help us understand and perceive the world around us. However, there are other human senses in addition to the basic five. These lesser-known senses include spatial awareness and balance. Here's how the human senses work.

research.title: The Five Senses - Visible Body
research.summary: The provided text is a website navigation menu for Visible Body, an anatomy learning resource.  It does not contain information about the specifics of touch, sight, and hearing beyond listing the general topic "The Five Senses" as a page. Therefore, no summary about the specifics of these senses can be provided from this text.
highlights: The nervous system must receive and process information about the world outside in order to react, communicate, and keep the body healthy and safe. Much of this information comes through the sensory organs: the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and skin. Specialized cells and tissues within these organs receive raw stimuli and translate them into signals the nervous system can use. Nerves relay the signals to the brain, which interprets them as sight (vision), sound (hearing), smell (olfaction), taste (gustation), and touch (tactile perception). The eyes sit in the orbits of the skull, protected by bone and fat.

research.title: Senses and Sensibility: Experiencing the World Around Us
research.summary: The provided text states that sight, touch, and hearing are among the five commonly understood senses (along with taste and smell),  plus two additional senses, vestibular and proprioception.  Harvard Catalyst funded research in this area in 2021, soliciting proposals on sensory perception and the human sensory system.
highlights: Building on this concept, a pair of headphones switch the communication of left and right sounds, so sounds from the left are heard as if they are on the right, and vice versa. The effect is that one must rely completely on vision rather than on sound to localize where the sound is coming from. Another project focuses on cochlear hair cells, which are the sensory cells that detect sound. One of the most common causes of permanent hearing loss is the irreversible damage and loss of these inner ear cells. Innovative strategies are needed to regenerate these cells and recover hearing.

nodes.text: Early childhood development heavily relies on sensory experiences.
nodes.label: Early childhood development
nodes.reason: Independent research strongly supports the claim that early childhood development relies on sensory experiences, highlighting their critical role in cognitive, motor, and emotional development.

research.title: The Importance of Early Sensory Experiences in Development
research.summary: Early childhood development significantly depends on sensory experiences.  From birth, babies learn through touch, hearing, sight, taste, smell, and movement.  Positive sensory experiences—like singing, bouncing, and playing with textured objects—strengthen brain connections, supporting learning and development into adulthood.  The article details age-appropriate sensory activities, emphasizing the importance of a diverse range of stimulation while noting that overstimulation should be avoided.  Lack of sensory input can stunt brain development.
highlights: Sensory play not only positively impacts your baby now, but the connections that are made help to support learning and development even into adulthood. A baby who is not given the same diverse set of opportunities and is kept in a swing all day or is kept in a very dark quiet environment can have their learning and brain development stunted by lack of exposure to sensory stimuli. - 0-3 months: Singing, bouncing, talking, swinging, bath time, massage, hanging a colorful mobile for the baby to look at, placing rattles in baby’s hand for exploration - 3-6 months: At this point you can add tummy time, play with food (purees), reading, encourage baby to touch fabrics with different textures, and shaking rattles - 6-9 months: Now you can start to blow bubbles, play in different positions on the floor, play with cause and effect toys and games such as play peek-a-boo

research.summary: Early childhood development significantly depends on sensory experiences.  Infants and toddlers learn about the world through their senses (sight, hearing, touch, taste, smell, proprioception, vestibular sense, and interoception), impacting emotional, cognitive, and physical development.  Sensory stimulation creates synapses in the brain, and consistent stimulation strengthens these connections, forming the foundation for learning and perception.  The text provides examples of activities to support sensory development in babies and toddlers, emphasizing the importance of providing appropriate sensory experiences while being mindful of avoiding overstimulation.
highlights: Babies start absorbing the sights, smells, sounds, tastes and textures around them as soon as they are born. Not only can you start providing rich sensory experiences for your newborn right away, exploring the world together is a lovely, simple way of

research.title: Importance of Sensory Activities in Early Childhood Development
research.summary: Sensory activities are crucial for early childhood development, impacting physical, mental, emotional, and social skills.  These activities enhance linguistic development by encouraging children to describe sensations, expanding their vocabulary.  They also improve motor skills, from large muscle movements (like splashing) to fine motor skills (like writing).  Furthermore, sensory play offers therapeutic benefits, helping regulate behavior and reduce stress in children.  Examples include sand play (developing creativity and fine motor skills), scented rice (promoting communication and cooperation), and water balloon activities (teaching about buoyancy and weight).
highlights: Sensory activities such as splashing in a pool or chasing butterflies teach children how to activate large muscle groups. They also teach finer motor skills necessary for more intricate tasks such as writing, drawing, playing an instrument, and tying knots. Arts and crafts-based activities encourage children to adapt their movements to different situations. **Sensory activities can be therapeutic** Children are full of energy and curiosity. A surplus of either can lead to hyperactivity.

nodes.text: Abstract concepts are difficult to convey solely through language.
nodes.label: Abstract concepts
nodes.reason: Independent research supports the notion that abstract concepts are challenging to convey purely through language, as effective communication often requires supplementary methods such as examples, visuals, or simplified language to ensure understanding.

research.title: Boost your communication skills with the “ladder of abstraction”
research.summary: The article supports this query by explaining the "curse of knowledge," a cognitive bias where communicators assume shared knowledge, leading to ineffective communication of abstract concepts.  It introduces the "ladder of abstraction" as a tool to overcome this.  This ladder visually represents how concrete details (like a specific cow, "Bessie") become increasingly abstract (e.g., "asset," "wealth") as you move up the rungs.  Effectively communicating abstract ideas requires moving down the ladder to more concrete examples and details, making the concepts understandable to the audience.
highlights: Engaging content on the skills that matter, taught by world-class experts. First proposed by the semanticist, and one-time Senator, Samuel I. Hayakawa, the ladder of abstraction is, obviously, a rather abstract concept. To help explain it in his 1939 book, Language in Action, Hayakawa employed the aid of Bessie the cow. Bessie is a beaut of a bovine and has many characteristics that make her unique from all other cows. When we speak or write of her, we are discussing an individual cow with those characteristics.

research.title: How to Write About Abstract Concepts | HackerNoon
research.summary: The article argues that abstract concepts, prevalent in technology (like APIs), are challenging to explain to a non-technical audience.  The author emphasizes the importance of using plain English to avoid alienating readers and ensure clear communication.  Failure to do so can result in lost sales and misunderstandings.  The article suggests that using simple language allows readers to quickly grasp the information and decide if the information is relevant to them.
highlights: There are often concepts that exist in a purely abstract way. We therefore have to find ways to explain what these concepts are so that they make sense to as many people as possible. Using complex language makes you sound smarter and isolates readers, putting them off even finishing reading your sales page. Using plain English means that readers instantly know who you are and what you do. They can make an informed decision about if you’re the right fit for them faster, or decide that they want to find out more.

research.title: The Use of Images for Abstract Words Versus Concrete Words: A Semiotic Study
research.summary: This study investigates the effectiveness of using semiotics (visual aids) to teach abstract versus concrete words to EFL learners.  The results showed that incorporating semiotics improved vocabulary acquisition for both abstract and concrete words compared to traditional teaching methods. However,  the benefit was more pronounced for concrete words.  This suggests that while visual aids can help with abstract concepts, they are more effective when teaching words with readily observable referents.
highlights: education, particularly language learning and teaching. Semiotics can play a very vital role in the field of language learning and teaching. Sert (2006) suggests that the implementation of semiotic theories to learning has recently gained noteworthy importance and led to the advent of a new field of study called educational semiotics. The semiotic approach, it can be argued, helps a great deal in making students learn a language in

nodes.text: Language has limitations in expressing complex ideas and experiences.
nodes.label: Communication limitations
nodes.reason: The claim is well-supported by independent research highlighting how language inherently limits expression, particularly concerning emotions, nuances, and individual cultural experiences, demonstrating that not all complex ideas can be effectively communicated.

research.title: Limitations of language
research.summary: This article details the limitations of language in expressing complex thoughts and experiences.  The author uses the analogy of painting a sunset to illustrate how language, being linear and inherently ambiguous, fails to capture the richness and nuance of reality.  Further limitations include a lack of words for all concepts, inconsistent understanding across individuals, and a poor capacity for conveying emotions.  The author notes their own improvement in writing over time, but still finds language a challenging tool.
highlights: words often have large differences in interpretation. The single problem that I have heard mentioned most often by others is expressing emotions and nuances from spoken language or body language in writing: Intonation, facial expression, hand gestures, ..., are all missing. This is not something that I personally have ever been very bothered by;

research.title: The Limits of Language
research.summary: The article uses Wittgenstein's philosophy to illustrate the limitations of language.  Wittgenstein's early work attempted to define a logical relationship between language and reality, influencing fields like computer science and linguistics. However, he later rejected this view, arguing that language's meaning is context-dependent and that the process of verifying truth is neither objective nor clearly defined.  The article concludes that language's meaning cannot be separated from its context, highlighting the inherent limitations in expressing complex ideas and experiences.
highlights: Instead, language should be studied from the starting point of its practices, rather from abstractions to syntax and semantics. As Wittgenstein put it, “Speaking a language is part of an activity, or of a form of life.” Unfortunately, this makes the study of language considerably more difficult, since examining the meanings of words now requires not just verbal definitions, but analyzing the whole “language-game” of situations and practices to which they are attached. Wittgenstein introduces the idea of “following a rule” to describe what we do when we use a word in everyday life, but what it is to “follow a rule” is notoriously difficult to pin down. Pears’ interpretation was that following a rule was akin to a judge applying a law in a case: Its validity depends on the past instances of how that rule was used, but also may set a new precedent for how that rule may be used in the future.

research.title: English is a limiting language that prevents us from communicating with complexity
research.summary: This article argues that English, and other colonial languages, limit the expression of complex ideas and experiences. The author, Ayesha Khan, describes how,  growing up in various countries and adapting to different cultural settings, she consciously toned down her expressive Indian accent and mannerisms to fit in with American culture.  This process, she reflects, involved suppressing aspects of her communication style that were considered "too much" or "too foreign," demonstrating how the perceived limitations of English led to a loss of nuanced expression.  She suggests that this experience highlights how the dominance of certain languages can hinder the communication of complexity and promote a homogenization of expression.
highlights: “Now, when the colonized subject wishes to speak of herself, or of the condition of her being, there is a fundamental shortcoming because this new language creates a ridge where there is a “patent difference that separates what \[s\]he says from what \[s\]he would like to say” (Sartre 1964, 24). **In the movement of her feeling, to thought, to its expression through speech, there is a key aspect of meaning fundamentally** **lost in translation**. The incapacity of the colonial language to express the fear and anxieties of the colonized, subdue and mute those feelings to the point where she is now only able to express all that the language allows her to, all that the colonist has the capacity to comprehend. The **nuances, complexities and subtleties of emotion and affect which are unique to her have no outlet, no way of being brought out into the world, remaining trapped in the body** of the colonized… What is expressed is some form of what is felt, but misses the true embodiment by more than just a sliver.” [!

nodes.text: The scientific method relies on observation and experimentation.
nodes.label: Scientific method
nodes.reason: The claim is mostly supported by independent research, which outlines that the scientific method incorporates observation as an essential step in formulating questions and hypotheses, and experimentation as a means of testing those hypotheses.

research.title: The Scientific Method: A Need for Something Better? - PMC
research.summary: This article questions the universality and necessity of the scientific method, particularly in fields outside the natural sciences.  While acknowledging its importance in areas like biology, physics, and chemistry, the author points out that  "soft sciences" (e.g., sociology, economics) often produce valuable results and even Nobel Prize-winning work without strictly adhering to it. The article highlights that the scientific method is better understood as a set of techniques to prove or disprove hypotheses, which themselves are proposed explanations for observed phenomena, often gathered through observation and/or experimentation.  The author argues that much of what we know, particularly in areas like economics and history, is based solely on observation and thought rather than rigorous experimental testing.
highlights: Despite its rigid structure, the scientific method still depends on the most human capabilities: creativity, imagination, and intelligence; and without these, it cannot exist. Documentation of experiments is always flawed because everything cannot be recorded. One of the most significant problems with the scientific method is the lack of importance placed on observations that lie outside of the main hypothesis (related to lateral thinking). No matter how carefully you record what you observe, if these observations are not also submitted to the method, they cannot be accepted. This is a common problem found by paleontologists who really have no way of testing their observations; yet many of their observations (primary and secondary) are accepted as valid.

research.title: Steps of the Scientific Method - Science Buddies
research.summary: The scientific method is a process of experimentation used to explore observations and answer questions.  While not all scientists follow it exactly, especially when direct experimentation is impossible (e.g., studying star evolution), the core principles remain:  discovering cause-and-effect relationships through questioning, evidence gathering, and logical analysis.  The process begins with a question, followed by background research.  A hypothesis is then formulated and tested through experimentation.  Data analysis determines whether the hypothesis is supported or refuted, leading to further research or a revised hypothesis.  Observation and experimentation are fundamental throughout this iterative process.
highlights: The six steps of the scientific method include: 1) asking a question about something you observe, 2) doing background research to learn what is already known about the topic, 3) constructing a hypothesis, 4) experimenting to test the hypothesis, 5) analyzing the data from the experiment and drawing conclusions, and 6) communicating the results to others. - _Ask a Question:_ Why does Greenland look so large on a map? - _Background Research:_ Learn that Greenland is a quarter the size of the United States in land mass. Also learn that Mercator projection maps are made by transferring the images from a sphere to a sheet of paper wrapped around the sphere in a cylinder. - _Hypothesis:_ If I make a Mercator projection map, then the items in the middle of the map will look their true size and the items at the poles will look larger than they really are.

research.title: Steps of the Scientific Method
research.summary: The scientific method is a process of experimentation used to explore observations and answer questions.  While not all scientists follow it exactly, the core goal remains discovering cause-and-effect relationships.  This involves asking questions, gathering and examining evidence, and constructing a logical answer.  The process begins with observation and the formulation of a testable hypothesis, followed by experimentation to gather data which is then analyzed to support or refute the hypothesis.  If the hypothesis is disproven, the process is repeated with a revised hypothesis.  Direct experimentation isn't always possible, leading scientists to modify the method, but the core principles remain.
highlights: The six steps of the scientific method include: 1) asking a question about something you observe, 2) doing background research to learn what is already known about the topic, 3) constructing a hypothesis, 4) experimenting to test the hypothesis, 5) analyzing the data from the experiment and drawing conclusions, and 6) communicating the results to others. - _Ask a Question:_ Why does Greenland look so large on a map? - _Background Research:_ Learn that Greenland is a quarter the size of the United States in land mass. Also learn that Mercator projection maps are made by transferring the images from a sphere to a sheet of paper wrapped around the sphere in a cylinder. - _Hypothesis:_ If I make a Mercator projection map, then the items in the middle of the map will look their true size and the items at the poles will look larger than they really are.

nodes.text: Many practical skills are learned through practice and experience.
nodes.label: Practical skills
nodes.reason: Independent research supports the idea that practical skills are often acquired through practice and experience, which enhances self-reliance and adaptability in various situations.

research.title: How To Doo
research.summary: The webpage lists 50 practical skills everyone should know, emphasizing self-reliance.  Examples include building a fire, basic computer operation, effective Google searching, CPR/Heimlich maneuver, driving a manual transmission, basic cooking, and captivating storytelling.  The author argues that mastering these diverse skills is more valuable than specializing in a single area.  The list provides links to resources for learning each skill.
highlights: Self-reliance is a vital key to living a healthy, productive life. To be self-reliant one must master a basic set of skills, more or less making them a jack of all trades. Contrary to what you may have learned in school, a jack of all trades is far more equipped to deal with life than a specialized master of only one. - [How To Help Someone Use a Computer](http://polaris.gseis.ucla.edu/pagre/how-to-help.html) - [The BBC’s Guide to Using a Computer](http://www.bbc.co.uk/computertutor/computertutorone/index.shtml)

research.title: Learn New Skills in 15 Hours: The Essential Guide - The Startup - Medium
research.summary: This Medium article by Danny Forest explores how to learn new skills efficiently.  While the full article is behind a paywall, the introduction notes that learning new skills isn't as daunting as it seems.  The author, having learned 40+ skills in 14 months, shares a method involving four steps to acquire a new skill in under 20 hours.  The article also discusses the nature of skills, reasons for learning them, whether mastery is necessary, and next steps after initial learning.  The article's emphasis aligns with the user's query, highlighting that practical skill acquisition is achievable through focused effort and a structured approach.
highlights: **Psychological research is clear: when people procrastinate, there's usually a good reason**](https://medium.com/human-parts/laziness-does-not-exist-3af27e312d01?source=read_next_recirc-----5f69582a6073----0---------------------9b434c43_7116_4df6_b104_663874f86c5b-------) **many ways to start a passive income today**](https://medium.com/@hazelparadise/how-i-create-passive-income-with-no-money-b9fc4ca219ba?source=read_next_recirc-----5f69582a6073----1---------------------9b434c43_7116_4df6_b104_663874f86c5b-------) 19 stories·2403 saves](https://medium.com/@MediumStaff/list/stories-to-help-you-live-better-467b590560f8?source=read_next_recirc-----5f69582a6073--------------------------------) 20 stories·1985 saves](https://medium.com/@MediumForTeams/list/productivity-101-f09f1aaf38cd?source=read_next_recirc-----5f69582a6073--------------------------------) 20 stories·2239 saves](https://medium.com/@MediumForTeams/list/selfimprovement-101-3c62b6cb0526?source=read_next_recirc-----5f69582a6073--------------------------------)

research.title: The Most Useful Life Skills That Everyone Should Know
research.summary: The article "The Most Useful Life Skills That Everyone Should Know" argues that many essential life skills are best learned through practice and experience.  It encourages readers to contribute to a collaborative list of these skills, highlighting their usefulness (e.g., saving money, handling emergencies) and providing explanations or links for learning them.  The article itself doesn't list specific skills but sets the stage for a crowdsourced compilation.
highlights: > Explanation of why the skill is useful. Is it one you should learn know so you have it in an emergency? Is it one that'll help you save money or live better every day? Is it one you constantly ask other people how to do? Whatever it is, explain it here—and if relevant, explain how to do it or give some links.

summary.reason: The overall score is an average of the subclaim scores, reflecting varying degrees of evidence supporting each subclaim.  Some subclaims require further research to strengthen their support for the root claim.
